Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Atomic and Magnetic Force Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the National Science Foundation to Morgan State University is for the acquisition of a combined atomic force and magnetic force microscope (AFM/MFM). This instrument will be used to probe the underlying physics and characterize thin magnetic films and multi-layers. In recent years, the PI has developed novel lower-dimensional solid state structures with optical, electronic, and magnetic characteristics governed by quantum mechanics. Probing the size effects and surface and interfacial physics is important in understanding these structures and developing new technologies. The AFM/MFM provides information on features as small as an atomic lattice for either conductive or non-conductive samples, it enables manipulation for sample growth, and it makes it possible to image in in-situ and controlled environments.

The ability to probe materials with Atomic and Magnetic Force Microscopy (AFM/MFM) is critical in understanding the physics of novel thin film magnetic materials a few nanometers thick and a few square millimeters in surface area. The instrument will be used to study technologically important materials used in ultra-high-density data storage for next generation personal computers and in developing fast, miniaturized, and reliable electronic devices. The instrument will complement an existing magneto-optic Kerr effect instrument and magnetron sputtering thin film growth system. Students at Morgan will learn the basics of operating and building an AFM / MFM through a weeklong workshop at the manufacturer's headquarters. This knowledge will enable modification of the instrument to advance a variety of research needs and will be passed on to future students at Morgan State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project evidence of significant induced magnetism was observed in multi-layer graphene (MLG), a two-dimensional surface of carbon atoms bonded together in a hexagonal honeycomb lattice, when coated by nano-magnetic Fe3O4 (magnetite) particles [1]. The induced magnetism is four times higher and is interpreted to be induced proximity ferromagnetism as shown in Figure 1. This effect of proximity induced ferromagnetism in graphene will lead to several applications of graphene such as high speed and light weight computers and sensors that will improve quality of life.

Also investigated is paramagnetic Co3O4 at room temperature coated on MLG and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) which was discovered to become ferromagnetic in the reduced crystalline symmetry of the interface layers in CNTs/ Co3O4 and MLG/ Co3O4 as shown magnetic force microscopy image is shown in Figure 2 [2]. These composites have many potential applications in optoelectronics and solid state sensors.            

Students at Morgan state university under the guidance of Dr. Dereje Seifu, MRI PI and Professor of Physics at Morgan State university presented their research results at several conference most notably at the American Physical Society (APS) March meeting in Baltimore MD in 2016 [3, 4]. Students are shown with their posters in pictures 1 and 2.

The PI presented his research results at the IEEE Nano International Nanotechnology Conference at Sendai, Japan. This research is a collaboration effort between Army Research Laboratory and two other universities [5].

Arrays of nanowires were synthesized by filling Fe/MgO/Fe in the lumens of vertically grown and substrate supported carbon nanotubes with magnetron DC and RF sputtering. Planar nanometric thin films of Fe/MgO/Fe tunneling magnetoresistance (TMR) structures were prepared by magnetron DC and RF sputtering on MgO(100). The magnetic properties of nanowires and nanometric thin films of Fe/MgO/Fe were investigated using several magnetometry techniques. Several similarities in the magnetic properties of nanowires and nanometric thin films were observed, such as two-fold magnetic symmetry and ratio of orbital moment to spin moment. Nanowires of Fe/MgO/Fe showed superior magnetic properties compared to planar thin films of Fe/MgO/Fe. The stipe domains shown in the MFM image of Fe/MgO/Fe nanowires in Figure 3 indicates the perpendicular anisotropy responsible for the formation of stripe domains resulted from strain magnetostriction and microstructure shape effect in the nanowires. In thin films stripe domains were not observed (MFM not shown here), this indicates the shape anisotropy in nanowires give it superior magnetic properties compared to planar films [6].

In a related project magnetic measurements showed that Cu capped Fe/MgO(100) nanometric thin films and Cu capped nanowires of Fe using MWCNTs as templates, nanowires exhibited higher anisotropy requiring higher saturation field compared to planar thin films due to magnetic shape anisotropy as shown in Figure 4 [7].
